ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to do hard investigative work, navigate complicated ethical quandries in journalism, expand my definition of what journalism is.

I learned how to structure a longform essay, conduct an interview and navigate the ethics of interviewing, request information, write muscle and nut graphs, and treat difficult topics with care and intention.
How to get in-depth reporting, the types of questions to ask, the details to include, and how to edit other peoples work
long form journalism, writing a pitch
It's a great opportunity to work on substantial reporting projects that you can even continue outside of school. And you learn a lot of essential skills: interviews, public records, etc.
I got to pursue writing projects that I really cared about! I learned about filing FOIA requests and skills for doing shoe-leather reporting.
I learned so much about being an investigative journalist, a more expansive, caring human being, a listener, a fighter.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Course is a really great way to not only learn about investigative reporting but work on some pieces ourselves and be able to speak with journalists who've been doing this type of work for years. I did feel like the timeline was hurried at time  two big investigative pieces in one semester when we all also had other class commitments did feel like too much, especially since we're also expected to revise at least one of them. I felt like the quality of my pieces suffered given the timeline.

Strengths: You really do have to write to longform essays. While that was really difficult and often felt like a negative, I'm ultimately SO glad I did it. I now how two publishable pieces that I'm more proud of than just about any essay I've written at Yale. Doing is the best way to learn, and while Professor Stillman holds your hand through some of the process, it's really up to you to request information, conduct interviews, and write the damn thing. The workshops are also very helpful.

Weaknesses: the discussions about other articles sometimes seemed superfluous to the workshop process, filling the 2.5hr time slot (which could be shortened).
sarah stillman is incredible! its a great opportunity to have a reason to write and workshop longform pieces

I loved this class. Prof. Stillman is an incredible and dedicated professor who is so generous with her time and mentorship. It's also a great way to work with talented writers/reporters from many different background. However, I did find that the two assignments were a lot of work it would be great to have focused on making one polished reporting piece throughout the semester.

Strengths: Prof. Stillman is the most kind, compassionate, supportive, warm professor to walk this planet. I learned so much not just about writing, but also about teaching and about being a good person from her.

Weakness: I thought the workshop format wasnt the MOST effective - we each wrote a 150word comment to each person whose draft was going to be workshopped, and a lot of the discussion in class was kind of repeating the somewhat surface level comments we already wrote. Could experiment with writing partners to edit more in depth, or small group discussions about pieces?

Strengths: Professor Stillman and the amount of time she makes for students
Weaknesses: Sometimes I didn't really know how to go about getting started on public records, etc., and feel presentations could have happened earlier in the course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they're interested in investigative journalism, absolutely. You get learn from Sarah Stillman who's an absolutely incredible reporter, and get to embark on two projects of your own. But I would recommend treating this class as your main commitment  otherwise, your pieces will suffer,

If you're at all interested in investigative journalism, yes. There were some days where I was overwhelmed by the work I needed to do in this classit's more outside work than just about any seminar, and the pieces feel higher stakes because you're engaging with real people and intense subjects. I took this class while writing my thesis, and some days I had to ignore this class or my thesis to finish work in the other class. All of this being said, on the other side, I am so glad I took this class. I now have two publishable pieces, an incredible mentor in Stillman, and have learned so many of the basics for journalism.
yes, fun class with good learning
Yes! Absolutely! One of the best writing classes at Yale for sure.
Id recommend if you dont have a lot of reporting experience. If you do, be prepared for the class to feel intro level, but youll get an amazing mentor and meet amazing classmates out of it.

I would! I haven't met a professor more passionate and student-centered than Professor Stillman. It's a tough, demanding course, but you will always have friends who will relate to your troubles and joys.
Definitely, if you're interested in justice oriented writing. Professor Stillman is an amazing person and the most incredible editor!
